title: Performance: map.js clones entire scene on every map open
description: In map.js showMap() and renderSmartphoneMap(), every time the map is opened, the entire terrain, all water bodies, all trees, and all bushes are cloned into a temporary scene. For 600 trees with GLTF models, this is expensive. The map also creates a new WebGLRenderer in renderSmartphoneMap() (line 758) every time. Consider caching the map scene and only updating marker positions, or rendering the map to an offscreen texture once and overlaying markers on a 2D canvas.

title: Code Quality: map.js creates inline styles programmatically
description: In map.js createSmartphoneMapModal() (lines 544-748), the entire smartphone map modal UI is built programmatically with inline CSS styles via style.cssText. This is ~200 lines of JavaScript string templates containing CSS. This makes the styling impossible to override from style.css, difficult to maintain, and inconsistent with the rest of the UI which uses CSS classes. Should move these styles to style.css and use class-based styling, or at minimum use CSS custom properties for the brand colors that are hardcoded throughout (e.g. #9eb529, #5f4d4d, #beb5a3, #ba5216).

title: Code Quality: player.js exceeds 900 lines - needs refactoring
description: player.js is 937 lines long, exceeding the 500-line guideline. It handles too many concerns: movement, camera controls, stamina, scope sway, kneeling, mouse/keyboard input, pointer lock, human tracks, tree bracing, wheel movement, foliage/water sound detection, and noise level calculation. Should be split into focused modules such as: player-input.js (keyboard/mouse/wheel handlers), player-movement.js (movement, stamina, kneeling), player-camera.js (mouse look, scope, sway), player-tracks.js (human track creation/update).

title: Code Quality: Excessive console.log statements in production code
description:
Many modules contain verbose console.log statements with emoji prefixes that should be removed or gated behind DEBUG_MODE for production. Examples:

- world.js: 15+ console.log calls with grass/trail debug info (lines 572, 610, 652, 657, 660, 756, 764, etc.)
- trails.js: 6+ console.log calls logging trail generation details (lines 25, 37, 179, 198, 284, etc.)
- ui.js: console.log on line 76, 167, 175, 500, 566-589
- map.js: console.log on line 281
- report-logger.js: console.log on line 23, 59
- deer-effects.js and wound-system.js: multiple console.log calls

constants.js already has a DEBUG_MODE flag. These logs should either be removed or wrapped in if(DEBUG_MODE) checks.

title: Bug: Perlin noise seed randomized on every height query
description: In world.js line 123, the getHeightAt() function creates a new ImprovedNoise instance and generates a random noiseZ seed on every call when noiseZ is undefined: 'const noiseZ = perlinParams.noiseZ === undefined ? Math.random() * 100 : perlinParams.noiseZ'. For the Alpine Forest and Desert Canyon presets in world-presets.js, noiseZ is set to Math.random() * 100 at module load time, so it is consistent within a session. However, if any preset omits noiseZ, every height query would produce different terrain, causing objects to float or sink. The fallback getHeightAt in createHills (line 97) would use a different random seed than the initial terrain generation. Should store the seed once during terrain creation and reuse it.

title: Bug: Duplicate map rendering logic in map.js
description: map.js contains two nearly identical map rendering functions: showMap() (line 188) and renderSmartphoneMap() (line 753). Both create temporary scenes, clone terrain/water/trees/bushes, add player and deer markers, and render. This is ~200 lines of duplicated logic. The deer marker logic (alive/wounded/dead/tagged) is copy-pasted between both functions. Any future changes to map rendering must be made in two places, risking divergence. Should extract shared rendering logic into a common function.

title: Bug: UI element references overwritten in initUI()
description: In ui.js lines 79-124, several gameContext UI element references are assigned twice. For example: timeValueElement is set to clock-value on line 79 then overwritten with time-value on line 122. interactionPromptElement set on line 88 then overwritten on line 111. scoreValueElement set on line 86 then overwritten on line 118. crosshairElement set on line 94 then overwritten on line 113. messageElement set to message-container on line 89 then overwritten with message on line 116. Whichever DOM element ID actually exists depends on which assignment runs last. If only the first ID exists, it gets overwritten with null, causing runtime errors.

title: Feature: Add spatial partitioning for vegetation collision checks
description: Currently, tree and bush collision detection in collision.js, deer-movement.js, and world.js uses linear scans through all vegetation objects. With 600 trees and potentially hundreds of bushes, this is O(n) per check and called multiple times per frame. A simple grid-based spatial hash would reduce lookups to O(1) amortized. The grid could be built once after world generation and queried by deer movement, player collision, and trail generation. This would also fix the MAX_TREES_TO_CHECK limit issue where nearby trees can be missed.

title: Bug: deer-effects.js texture loaded repeatedly for each blood indicator
description: In deer-effects.js createShotBloodIndicator() (line 183), a new TextureLoader is created and the blood_drops.png texture is loaded from disk every time a shot blood indicator is created. Unlike createTrack() and createBloodDrop() which lazily initialize materials once, createShotBloodIndicator has no caching. Each shot triggers a fresh texture load. Should cache the material like the other methods do, or share the bloodDropMaterial.

title: Performance: Excessive THREE.Vector2/Vector3 allocations in hot paths
description:
Multiple modules create new THREE.Vector2 and THREE.Vector3 objects inside per-frame or frequently-called functions, causing GC pressure:

1. collision.js checkTreeCollision() line 253: 'new THREE.Vector2(...)' on every tree distance check
2. collision.js checkBushCollision() line 305: same pattern for bushes
3. deer-movement.js moveWithCollisionDetection() line 263: 'new THREE.Vector2(...)' inside water check loop
4. deer-ai.js line 657: 'new THREE.Vector3(0,0,0).sub(...)' in emergency escape
5. world.js isWaterAt() line 947: Math.sqrt computed but could use distanceSq comparison

These are called every frame or multiple times per frame. Should use pre-allocated reusable vectors (like spatial-audio.js already does with _relativePos, _cameraRight etc) to reduce garbage collection pauses.

title: Code Quality: map.js exceeds 870 lines - needs refactoring
description: map.js is 871 lines long, exceeding the 500-line guideline. The createSmartphoneMapModal() function alone is ~200 lines of programmatic DOM/CSS creation. Should be split into: map-renderer.js (shared rendering logic for both map views), map-ui.js (smartphone modal creation, battery UI), map-core.js (initMap, showMap, marker creation).

title: Bug: deer-movement.js updateDeerHeight called 3 times per frame
description: In deer-movement.js moveWithCollisionDetection(), updateDeerHeight() is called up to 3 times per movement frame: once on line 319 (collision revert path), once on line 325 (normal path), once on line 369 (emergency tree push), and once on line 374 (final safety). Each call does a terrain raycast which is expensive. Should restructure to call updateDeerHeight() exactly once at the end of the function regardless of code path.

title: Bug: player.js hardcoded initial position doesn't match ui.js
description: In ui.js advanceToNextDay() lines 469-472, the player is reset to position (60, y, 60). But in world.js createTrees() line 359, trees avoid spawning near position (0, y, 10). The player spawn avoidance radius is centered at (0, y, 10) but the actual player start position is (60, y, 60). This means trees could spawn right at the player's actual starting position. The initial player position should be defined as a constant in constants.js and referenced consistently.

title: Bug: spatial-audio.js exponentialRampToValueAtTime used incorrectly
description: In spatial-audio.js line 193, the fade-out effect uses volume.volume.exponentialRampToValueAtTime(). However, Tone.js Volume uses decibel values which can be negative. The exponentialRampToValueAtTime Web Audio API method cannot ramp to negative values (it requires positive values). This will throw an error or produce unexpected behavior when targetVolume is negative (which it always will be since currentVolume is in dB and targetVolume = currentVolume - 6). Should use linearRampToValueAtTime or Tone.js rampTo() method instead.

title: Bug: world-presets.js Alpine/Desert seeds change on every page load
description: In world-presets.js lines 34 and 64, the Alpine Forest and Desert Canyon presets use 'noiseZ: Math.random() * 100' which is evaluated at module load time. This means every page refresh generates a completely different terrain layout for these presets. While this provides variety, it makes debugging terrain issues impossible and means players can never revisit a familiar map. Should use a fixed seed per preset (e.g. noiseZ: 42.7) or implement a seed-based system where the seed is displayed and can be shared/replayed.

title: Bug: camera-effects.js recoil recovery doesn't restore original rotation
description: In camera-effects.js, the rifle recoil recovery animation settles at a 'varied recovery target' that includes random offsets from the original rotation (lines 44-51). recoveryOffsetX/Y/Z add up to ±0.05/0.06/0.025 radians of permanent drift per shot. Over multiple shots, the camera rotation accumulates random drift that never gets corrected. This means the player's aim permanently shifts after each shot. The recovery should return to the original rotation, or the offsets should be dramatically smaller.

title: Bug: hunting-mechanics.js shoot() fires penalty before checking deer exists
description: In hunting-mechanics.js shoot() lines 212-229, the after-hours shooting penalty is applied and score is updated BEFORE the function checks if the deer model is loaded (line 231) or if the deer is in the scene (line 236). This means if the deer hasn't loaded yet, the player still gets penalized for shooting after hours, but the shot itself is discarded with a message. The penalty check should be moved after the deer existence checks, or the early return should also skip the penalty.

title: Bug: Desert Canyon preset has no water bodies for deer drinking
description: In world-presets.js, the Desert Canyon preset has a single small water body (size 77) positioned at (-250, y, -250), far from the map center. The deer spawns and wanders primarily in the center of the map. With the deer's water-seeking behavior (THIRSTY state), the deer may never find water because the drinking spot search in world.js findDrinkingSpots() scans terrain vertices near water level, but the oasis is very small and remote. The deer could get stuck in THIRSTY state walking toward unreachable water. Should either add more water sources or adjust deer AI to handle maps with distant/no water.

title: Code Quality: hunting-mechanics.js exceeds 800 lines - needs refactoring
description: hunting-mechanics.js is 821 lines long, exceeding the 500-line guideline. The shoot() function alone is ~270 lines (lines 206-672) with deeply nested conditionals. Should be split into focused modules such as: scoring.js (calculateBonuses, processKill, updateScoreDisplay), shot-processing.js (raycast, hit detection, accuracy deviation), tagging.js (tagDeer, tag bonuses).

title: Bug: Geometry not disposed in deer-effects.js createTrack/createBloodDrop
description: In deer-effects.js, createTrack() (line 62) and createBloodDrop() (line 152) create new PlaneGeometry objects for every track and blood drop. While the materials are disposed in updateTracks() and updateBloodDrops() when effects expire, the geometries are never disposed. Over a long play session with a wounded deer, hundreds of geometries accumulate without cleanup. The cleanup() method (line 266) also only disposes materials, not geometries. Should call track.mesh.geometry.dispose() alongside material disposal.

title: Bug: map.js trail rendering applies contradictory rotations
description:
In map.js showMap() lines 348-349, trail meshes have two contradictory rotation assignments:
  mapTrail.rotation.x = -Math.PI / 2; // Lay flat
  mapTrail.rotation.x = 0; // Already in XZ plane
The second line immediately overwrites the first. The comment says 'Already in XZ plane' suggesting the rotation isn't needed, but the first line suggests it is. One of these is wrong and should be removed.

title: Bug: collision.js unused variables in raycast hit zone selection
description: In collision.js raycast() lines 121-122, two arrays are defined but never used: 'const vitalZones' and 'const bodyZones'. These were likely intended for more sophisticated hit zone selection logic but the current implementation only uses a simple gut-to-rear priority check. The unused arrays should be removed to reduce confusion.

title: Bug: trails.js getTreeAvoidance iterates wrong object
description: In trails.js line 147-148, getTreeAvoidance() checks 'gameContext.trees.length' and iterates 'for (const tree of gameContext.trees)'. However, gameContext.trees is a THREE.Group, not an array. The correct access is gameContext.trees.children.length and gameContext.trees.children. The current code will always return null because a THREE.Group has no .length property (undefined is falsy), so tree avoidance during trail generation is completely non-functional.

title: Bug: world.js createGroundCover doesn't return a Promise
description: In world.js createGroundCover() line 851, the function uses setTimeout internally but doesn't return a Promise. If the caller awaits this function, it will resolve immediately before the grass is actually created. Unlike createGrass() which wraps its setTimeout in a Promise, createGroundCover fires and forgets. This means ground cover creation timing is unpredictable relative to other initialization steps.

title: Bug: deer-movement.js assumes 60fps for speed calculation
description: In deer-movement.js moveWithCollisionDetection() line 217, the current speed is calculated by multiplying the delta-adjusted speed by 60: 'this.currentSpeed = speed * 60'. This assumes a constant 60fps framerate. On slower machines or during GC pauses, the actual framerate could be lower, making the speed calculation inaccurate. Similarly on line 224, forced avoidance timer uses '1/60' instead of actual delta. Should pass delta as a parameter and use it for accurate time-based calculations.

title: Bug: Duplicate shooting stance calculation in processKill()
description: In hunting-mechanics.js processKill(), the shooting stance string (Offhand/Braced/Sitting/Sitting & Braced) is computed twice with identical logic: once on lines 151-158 for killInfo.shootingStance, and again on lines 181-188 for the logEvent call. Both use the same isBracedForInfo and isKneelingForInfo values. Should compute once and reuse.

title: Bug: world.js createGrass uses setTimeout for terrain readiness
description: In world.js createGrass() line 577, a 1-second setTimeout is used to delay grass creation until terrain is ready: 'setTimeout(() => { ... }, 1000)'. This is a race condition - on slow machines, terrain may not be ready in 1 second, and on fast machines, it wastes 1 second. Similarly, createGroundCover() uses a 100ms setTimeout on line 928. Should use proper async/await or event-based signaling to wait for terrain readiness instead of arbitrary timeouts.

title: Code Quality: ui.js exceeds 890 lines - needs refactoring
description: ui.js is 892 lines long, exceeding the 500-line guideline. It handles main menu, mode selection, loading animation, HUD toggle, report modal, map modal, instructions modal, season complete modal, world selector, compass, interaction prompts, status indicators, and next-day advancement. Should be split into: ui-modals.js (report, map, instructions, season-complete modals), ui-hud.js (HUD toggle, compass, status indicators), ui-menu.js (main menu, mode selection, world selector, loading).

title: Upgrade Three.js from r128 to r182
description: Upgrade Three.js from v0.128.0 (May 2021) to r182 (latest stable, Feb 2026). This is a major upgrade spanning 54 releases with significant breaking changes. Benefits include: BVH-accelerated raycasting, BatchedMesh for instanced rendering, WebGPU renderer support, improved shadow maps, better color management, physically correct lighting, and significant performance improvements. The codebase is in good shape (already uses BufferGeometry, InstancedMesh, ShaderMaterial, outputColorSpace) which reduces migration risk.

title: Update Three.js CDN import map from r128 to r182
description: Update index.html import map to point to Three.js r182 instead of r128. Switch from Skypack CDN to a more reliable CDN (unpkg or jsdelivr) since Skypack has had reliability issues. Update both 'three' and 'three/examples/jsm/' import paths. Files affected: index.html, index_backup.html, hitbox-studio.html.

title: Fix lighting: PointLight/SpotLight decay defaults and legacy lights removal
description: r147: PointLight and SpotLight decay default changed from 0 to 2 (physically correct). r155: WebGLRenderer.useLegacyLights deprecated and defaults to false. Must audit all PointLight/SpotLight usage in scene.js and environment-manager.js. Set decay=1 explicitly on existing lights to preserve current look, or tune intensity values for physically correct lighting. Files: scene.js, environment-manager.js, world.js.

title: Fix color management: ColorManagement.enabled and outputColorSpace defaults
description: r152: ColorManagement.enabled now defaults to true. outputColorSpace replaces outputEncoding. sRGBEncoding becomes SRGBColorSpace. Our code already uses outputColorSpace = THREE.SRGBColorSpace (good), but the new default ColorManagement.enabled=true may change how colors are interpreted in materials, textures, and vertex colors. Need to verify all Color() constructors and material colors still look correct. May need to explicitly set colorSpace on textures loaded via TextureLoader. Files: scene.js, environment-manager.js, world.js, map.js, deer-effects.js, trails.js.

title: Fix custom GLSL shaders for r182 compatibility
description: r154: shader chunk encodings_fragment renamed to colorspace_fragment, output_fragment renamed to opaque_fragment. r157: GeometricContext struct removed from GLSL. r163: WebGL 1 no longer supported. Must audit grass-shader.js and water-shader.js ShaderMaterial definitions for any use of removed/renamed shader chunks or GLSL constructs. Both shaders use custom vertex/fragment shaders that may reference internal Three.js shader chunks. Files: grass-shader.js, water-shader.js.

title: Fix GLTFLoader and model loading compatibility
description: r133: Raycaster.intersectObject/intersectObjects recursive parameter now defaults to true. r148: GLTFLoader ensures node order matches glTF asset. r151: InstancedMesh.frustumCulled now true by default and requires computeBoundingSphere() after instance matrix updates. Must verify deer GLB model loading still works correctly with updated GLTFLoader. Check AnimationMixer compatibility for deer animations. Files: deer.js, animal.js, world.js, preloader.js (all use GLTFLoader).

title: Fix InstancedMesh: computeBoundingSphere after matrix updates
description: r151: InstancedMesh.frustumCulled now defaults to true and requires computeBoundingSphere() after instance matrix updates for correct frustum culling and raycasting. Must add computeBoundingSphere() calls after instanceMatrix.needsUpdate in world.js grass creation (3 InstancedMesh usages). Without this fix, grass may disappear when camera rotates. Files: world.js.

title: Visual regression testing and lighting tuning after upgrade
description: After all code changes are applied, do a thorough visual regression test: verify terrain rendering, tree/bush materials, grass shaders, water shaders, shadow quality, deer model appearance, blood effects, map rendering, and overall lighting balance. Tune light intensities if physically correct lighting changes the look. Verify deer animations still play correctly. Test all game states: wandering, fleeing, wounded, killed. Files: all rendering-related files.

title: Bug: world.js createGrass creates raycaster per height query
description: In trails.js getTerrainOnlyHeight() line 128, a new THREE.Raycaster is created on every call. This function is called for every trail point during trail generation. Should create the raycaster once and reuse it. Similarly, world.js getHeightAt (the mathematical fallback on line 109) creates a new ImprovedNoise() instance on every call, which is wasteful for Perlin noise terrain.

title: Bug: Audio crossfade midnight handling has duplicate code
description: In audio.js updateAmbianceForTime(), the midnight cricket stop logic is duplicated: once on lines 495-507 checking gameTime >= CRICKET_END_TIME (24.0), and again on lines 511-523 checking gameTime >= 0.0 && gameTime < 0.1. Since CRICKET_END_TIME is 24.0 and game time likely wraps to 0, only one of these conditions can ever be true depending on how time wraps. If time wraps from 23.99 to 0.0, the first check (>=24.0) would never trigger. If time reaches exactly 24.0 before wrapping, the second check is redundant. Should consolidate into a single robust midnight detection.

title: Bug: context.js gameContext has stale/unused properties
description:
In context.js, the gameContext object defines many properties that appear unused or redundant:

1. gameContext.heightQueryCache (line ~220) is defined but getCachedHeightAt only checks this cache - if the cache is never populated externally, it always falls through to getHeightAt.
2. gameContext.morningCrossfadeTriggered is reset in ui.js advanceToNextDay() but never set to true anywhere.
3. gameContext.maxMapUsage is referenced in map.js line 408 but may not be initialized in context.js.
4. gameContext.batteryLevel and mapUsageCount are used in map.js but initialized in ui.js advanceToNextDay() rather than context.js.
5. gameContext.controls is referenced in camera-effects.js but never assigned.

Should audit all gameContext properties, remove unused ones, and ensure all used properties are properly initialized in context.js.

title: Bug: Tree collision check limits can miss nearby trees
description: In collision.js checkTreeCollision() (line 232), the MAX_TREES_TO_CHECK limit of 20 combined with iterating gameContext.trees.children in insertion order means the function may hit the limit before checking the closest trees. Trees are not spatially sorted, so the first 20 trees checked may all be far away while a nearby colliding tree is at index 21+. The roughDistance Manhattan check helps but doesn't guarantee the closest trees are checked first. Same issue exists in checkBushCollision() with MAX_BUSHES_TO_CHECK=15. Consider spatial partitioning (grid/quadtree) for O(1) lookups instead of linear scan.

title: Bug: Duplicate bonus calculation in processKill()
description: In hunting-mechanics.js, the calculateBonuses() function is called twice in processKill(): once on line 130 to compute the actual score, and again on line 148 to get bonusDetails for the killInfo object. Both calls use the same parameters and produce the same result. The second call is wasteful and risks divergence if parameters change between calls. Should store the full result from the first call and reuse it.

title: Bug: report-logger.js score calculation diverges from actual game score
description: In report-logger.js generateCurrentReport(), the score breakdown is reconstructed from scratch by re-examining killInfo, badShotPenalties, tagBonusInfo, etc. This parallel calculation can diverge from the actual gameContext.score which is updated incrementally in hunting-mechanics.js. For example: the report calculates baseKillScore based on hitZone (line 160-162) but doesn't account for shot angle penalties that were applied in hunting-mechanics.js. The report's finalScore (line 257) may not match gameContext.score displayed in the HUD. Should either derive the report from a single authoritative score ledger, or display gameContext.score directly.

title: Bug: player.js human track height calculated twice
description: In player.js createHumanTrack() lines 828-830, the track Y position is set twice: first to 'terrainHeight + 0.1' on line 828, then immediately overwritten with 'getCachedHeightAt() + 0.1' on lines 829-830. The first assignment is wasted. Should remove the redundant first assignment or consolidate into a single height calculation.

title: Bug: gameContext.clockValueElement referenced but never assigned
description: In ui.js advanceToNextDay() line 493, the code references gameContext.clockValueElement to update the clock display: 'if (gameContext.clockValueElement) { gameContext.clockValueElement.textContent = 04:30; }'. However, gameContext.clockValueElement is never assigned anywhere in the codebase. The initUI() function assigns gameContext.timeValueElement (lines 79 and 122). The environment-manager.js updateTimeDisplay() also uses gameContext.timeValueElement. This means the clock never updates when advancing to the next day.

title: Bug: audio.js startTitleMusic recursive setTimeout without limit
description: In audio.js startTitleMusic() line 344, if the title music hasn't loaded yet, it calls setTimeout(() => startTitleMusic(), 500) recursively. There is no retry limit or maximum wait time. If the audio file fails to load (network error, missing file), this will retry every 500ms indefinitely, creating an infinite loop of setTimeout calls. Should add a retry counter and give up after a reasonable number of attempts (e.g. 10 retries = 5 seconds).

title: Bug: wound-system.js findThickCover has O(n²) bush iteration
description: In wound-system.js findThickCover() lines 396-406, for each grid sample point, the code iterates ALL bushes to count nearby ones. Then for each bush, it iterates ALL other bushes to count density (lines 307-313 in findTargetLocation). This is O(gridPoints * bushes²) complexity. With 200+ bushes and a 150-unit search radius at 20-unit grid spacing, this is ~56 grid points * 200 * 200 = 2.24M iterations. Should use spatial partitioning or at minimum limit the inner bush density check to a smaller subset.
